poem:
In Memoriam: Dame Joan Plowright  

The curtain falls in silence now,  
a life once spent in dialogue,  
roots entwined with words of stage,  
Olivier's hand in Plowright's own—  
a union that spoke,  
in hushed tones,  
of change whispered in London's air.  
The theatre dims, then shines anew,  
a quiet nod to legacy.  
Applause.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Dame Joan Plowright obituary Joan Plowright, who has died aged 95, played a central role in the historic overhaul of British theatre at the Royal Court in the late 1950s. A founder member of George Devine’s English Stage Company in 1956, she made her name as Beatie Bryant, the working-class heroine in Arnold Wesker’s Roots in 1959, and married Laurence Olivier in 1961. The union of Plowright and Olivier was symbolic of the new theatre". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
